awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Characterizing the Regional Fluid Flow System of the Wyoming Salient, Sevier Fold-Thrust Belt: Implications for Orogenic Wedge Deformation and Propagation
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to investigate the role that crustal fluids have played in deformational processes that created the classic Wyoming salient of the Cordilleran fold and thrust belt of the western United States. The Cordilleran orogenic belt is a major tectonic feature consisting of folds and faults that resulted from convergent margin tectonic activity due to subduction of the Farallon plate beneath the North American plate about 140 to 50 million years ago during the Sevier Orogeny. The Wyoming salient is considered to be an ideal place for this study given that it has been extensively studied and is of the best characterized fold and thrust belts in the world. The results of the project will provide insights into how fluids contribute to large-scale deformation associated with mountain building events, fault zone processes, and the results will have implications for a variety of disciplines that have societal relevance, including mineral exploration, hydrocarbon exploration, hydrology. In addition to the research goals of the project, the project will contribute to training of graduate and undergraduate students in a STEM discipline; collaboration between three universities; contributions to research infrastructure at at Ph.D. granting and primary undergraduate institutions; incorporation of research results into classroom curricula; and dissemination of research results via peer-reviewed publications, presentations at professional geoscience meetings, and by web accessible digital data sets. 

This project will innovatively integrate detailed structural, fluid inclusion, stable isotope, and geochronologic studies along transects across the curved Wyoming salient into the foreland and along traverses of key large-scale folds and major fault zones, providing extensive new regional data sets that relate fluid flow with progressive deformation. Although previous laboratory studies have provided insights into deformation micromechanisms and previous field and modeling studies of thrust belts have revealed the importance of fault zones and evolving topography on fluid flow systems, quantitative interrelations between regional to local fluid flow and progressive deformation within propagating fold-thrust wedges remains poorly understood. This project will build on previous structural studies in the Wyoming salient, with results synthesized to improve our understanding of feedbacks between fluid flow and thrust wedge mechanics. The project will test models of fluid-flow systems within curved fold-thrust belts, including nature of micro-, meso-, and megascopic fluid pathways; changing contributions of meteoric-, formation-, and metamorphic-waters during progressive wedge propagation and development of topography; evolving stratigraphic and structural compartmentalization of fluid flow as deformation changes style from distributed layer-parallel shortening to concentrated thrust slip; and propagation of detachment faults and early layer-parallel shortening in front of the fold-thrust wedge related to enhanced fluid flow and burial. This project will build on previous structural studies in the Wyoming salient, with results synthesized to improve our understanding of feedbacks between fluid flow and wedge mechanics. The project will combine a variety of methodologies, including mesoscopic structural analysis and sampling of veins/fracture sets, cleavage, and minor faults that provided fluid pathways,

por.por_cntn:
This project improved understanding of the relations among deformation and fluid flow during evolution of a classic fold-thrust belt, the Wyoming salient of the Sevier belt, using integrated structural, geochemical, and geochronologic studies. The project promoted education and professional development of undergraduate and graduate students through collaborative research at three institutions. Students were involved in field and laboratory studies, presented results at professional meetings, and one PhD thesis was completed. 

 

Significant scientific findings are listed below: 

(1)Systematic suites of structures developed during progressive stages of deformation and fluid flow, including (i) early-stage layer-parallel shortening with development of spaced cleavage, minor faults, and bedding parallel and cross-strike bedding perpendicular veins, (ii) main-stage large-scale folding and concentrated slip on major thrust faults with additional cross cutting veins and faults forming along steeper fold limbs; (iii) late-stage, mostly passive transport above a very weak basal thrust fault. 

(2) Microstructural analysis confirmed the importance of mass-transfer deformation in limestone with dissolution of calcite along cleavage seams and precipitation of calcite in veins during protracted deformation. 

(3) Small inclusions of fluids trapped during sealing of veins provide a proxy record of fluid temperatures and compositions, with patterns indicating an evolving system with episodically elevated fluid pressures and localized influx of cooler (meteoric) fluids during major thrust faulting. 

(4) The oxygen, carbon and hydrogen isotopic compositions of calcite and clay, respectively, in veins and fault zones provide a proxy record for fluid isotopic compositions, sources, and pathways. The patterns indicate low-fluid rock ratios and mostly strata-bound fluids (within bedding units) during early layer-parallel shortening, followed by more focused flow with input of meteoric (surface) waters along major faults and cross-cutting veins in steep fold limbs. 

(5) Age dating of clays from cleavage seams and fault rocks indicates broadly Cretaceous (140 ? 50 million years) ages, but presence of multiple clay components complicated interpretation of precise ages.

Based on the findings of this collaborative research project, a general model for spatial and temporal patterns of fluid flow systems (sources, pathways, fluid-rock interactions, sinks) was developed. Fluid migration within the Jurassic Twin Creek Formation and the Triassic Thaynes Formation away from major faults and more fractured parts of large-scale folds was mostly confined within bedding units during early layer-parallel shortening. Fluid pressures likely varied during early deformation, from near lithostatic as dissolution of calcite decreased porosity, leading to a combination of tensile failure of veins and shear failure of minor faults. Dilatancy (increase in pore space caused by irregular fit between fractured fragments) during fracturing resulted in reduced fluid pressures and precipitation of calcite that sealed veins, with repeated cracking and sealing episodes. With progressive deformation, slip was concentrated along major thrust faults that propagated progressively from the back toward the front of the mountain belt. Longer, wider spaced fractures developed around associated large-scale folds, forming locally integrated networks that provided pathways for meteoric influenced fluids. Major fault zones acted as conduits for episodic influx of meteoric waters, as well as experiencing elevated fluid pressure and development of complex veins. We envision a model of fluid pressure cycling, possibly driven by seismic (earthquake) cycles, with downward pumping of meteoric fluids during episodes of large-scale failure and dilatancy.

 

Results of this project will aid in the understanding of fluid flow systems and structurally controlled hydrocarbon traps in fold-thrust belts. Geologic maps completed in collaboration with the Utah Geological Survey as part of this project provide information for ground water source development and protection.
